metadata.title: The Hard Truth of Why We Need Data Product Managers | by Dov Stern | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The Hard Truth of Why We Need Data Product Managers
metadata.description: Data is top of mind for most product managers. Models Will Run the World, with the big winners being those model-driven organizations that build products that collect data and continuously learn to…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: there is a small cottage industry of blogs

all_paragraphs: Data is top of mind for most product managers. Models Will Run the World, with the big winners being those model-driven organizations that build products that collect data and continuously learn to optimize growth, in turn accelerating that cycle. But the underside of that phenomenon is that at the core of any successful model is representative data. While the idea and the end product may be awe-inspiring and great for quarterly OKRs, it requires a lot of un-sexy effort. Just like software, data needs its own frameworks for managing this process in order to achieve successful outcomes — enter the Data Product Manager.
The Case for the Data Product Manager

I like to think of technology solutions as Maya — Indian philosophy’s term for the synthetic world of facts and events, imposed on the world through abstractions such as measuring, classification, division. The lifecycle of these solutions is its own kind of technological Karma (kind of like tech debt) — anytime we build a solution, it necessitates further action of quality control, maintenance, extension. The act of forcing technological Maya on the world is inherently anti-equilibrium, creating karmic consequences for the team and customers.

Under this view, the role of any good product manager is to pick the right problems, match them up with the right solutions, and groom the slopes for the team. Getting to the “goodness” of models running on representative data is no different: while the upside of a successful model is huge, there is an even larger potential for a black hole of complexity.

Data is no longer just making reports — data is becoming its own product domain, with its own deliverables, customers, development lifecycle and infrastructure needs. In order to meet expectations and avoid the chaos of go-it-alone hope-for-the-best analyses, we need product managers to steer these data products from ideation to completion.
“Product Management”, even more so in “Data”, is nebulous. Let’s define what that is.

Some organizations distinguish between more strategic & customer-focused “Product Managers” vs more implementation-focused “Product Owners.” Thankfully there is a small cottage industry of blogs that disparage this “horizontal” model, because we get a situation where the Product Owner won’t understand the customer, and the Product Manager won’t know what’s technically possible. The end result:
It’s nice that we tried to establish clear responsibilities, but we ended up with a high stakes game of broken telephone.

We need product managers who can connect between the business case and the technical details, serving as a partner to both customers and engineers. That means that the Product Manager takes on a larger, end-to-end role, focused on product strategy, prioritization, solutioning and delivery. Naturally, the Product Manager can’t do everything, and that’s where products ops/analysts come in, serving as day-to-day interfaces with customers, sizing up problems for prioritization, and ensuring the smooth delivery of solutions through UAT and rollouts.

This should make sense for any product team, but even more so for a data product team. Since the data product is basically a model of reality, product managers should be in touch with the reality of the customers, but also capable of fitting a technical solution to that reality. The Data Product Manager should be able to see the technical concept from start to finish, working with front-end product teams to collect useful data, with data engineering on ETL processes, with ML engineering on model development, all the way through to deployment. At this nexus, the Data Product Manager is responsible for the following stages in the data product lifecycle:

Data products are basically models of reality, and modelling reality is hard. As these models become more prevalent, we need good data product managers to lead this process from the front-lines, and we need to be clear on what that process is. I hope this article has helped clarify what that should entail.
